text: Now this is what I call Design... awesome breakdown of Disney's MagicBand system. This makes me want to go to DisneyWorld just for this experience alone. This really seems like a microcosm of the future.  <http://www.wired.com/2015/03/disney-magicband/>

attachments.title: Disney's $1 Billion Bet on a Magical Wristband | WIRED
attachments.text: The Magicband wields access to the park, replacing virtually every transaction you'd make inside. Bob Croslin If you want to imagine how the world will loo
attachments.fallback: WIRED: Disney's $1 Billion Bet on a Magical Wristband | WIRED

text: Do we have a new template we should be working with when presenting to clients???
not an official one. I have one that I created and have used, and I imagine Matt probably has one too. Happy to provide mine if it's helpful.
We should definitely create a standard one.
YES <@U0260V1BX>
I'm putting together a list of public facing/client facing templates and collateral we should start collecting and distributing
I'm pretty sure Matt has placed a bunch of stuff on the NAS for templates. Both internal decks and external decks. He can tell you more but there is something.
I think those are old though
unless there are updated ones
That's what we were using when I was making pitch decks, I've been off those for the most part for a while now. Didn't know they were outdated.
we're in a bit of a transitional state, brand-wise... with the new website debuting a new brand font, a lot of our keynotes have been updated and a lot haven't. It's wildly inconsistent right now.

Sweet. <@U0260V1BX> I'm inviting you to the trello I'm putting together right now. Maybe we can take a bit to go through what's good, what needs to be updated, and new things we should start collecting
that sounds great
thanks danielle
and <@U02F9CXTL>  i will send you some files
Awesome. Maybe for now we create a central location on the NAS
(if there isn't already)
Is there anything unofficially "official" that we should be using now? I just went back to the template from last fall when I made up the Sizzle deck.
I've been using a variation of the deck here: NAS > uncorked > style guide > Master Style Guide > _UncorkedStyleGuide2014.indd_
<@U02F9CXTL> I just posted the design/UX templates I"ve been using here: uncorked/Uncorked InDesign Templates 2015/Design/UX (Melissa)
We'll definitely need to create something as thorough as the 2014 one... mine are mostly design/UX focused
but we'll need something for pitch decks, reports, proposals, etc
I guess what I'm asking is what should I/we use before we have a new official template?
I suppose we should just continue using the old one for pitch decks
but we should get to steppin' on the new one

The thing I've always had difficulties with on pitch templates is font loading, can we make that a priority for the future of our templates? Being sure we all have (legal licensed) copies of brand fonts instead of janky bootleg copies that don't register cross-paltform.
good call
Thanks all!
sorry, lego meeting.

Yes, we've made some new-er ones, but there is nothing wrong with the old ones. In fact, they probably connect better with our site as it is now. While the new stuff is fun to try out, maybe we should wait until the site launches when we can come up with a new style guide.

Also, it's up to you how you want to show your work to your clients on your projects. Those are handy, and a good starting point, but there is no rule that says you have to use anything. Pitch decks have been operating the same way for years. They start as something, then they evolve. Plus, I don't think anyone is comparing our pitch decks for font licensing and consistency.
But, I'm more than happy to re-set / re-new everything as we get closer to the new site

theyre most certainly not. but i do hear trent's concern in that most times when i open a file it's a different version of gotham than i have installed. I think that will be way less of an issue with FF Mark because it's a newer font that all of us don't already have.
right. Gotham is tough because everyone has their own version. We purchased FF Mark, I can check the licensing and forward when we update
but the gotham fonts that I used to build the templates are on the NAS too

Yeah my issue is trying to share anything with anyone else. The licensing thing is a "should have" though not keeping us from completing things. It's more an issue when other people can't take over pitch decks I've worked on because of paragraph styles being set to read one version of Gotham when there's doesn't register. Just gets messy sometimes, but we've worked around it in the past. I think it's something we need to consider in the future, a learn from the past kind of thing.
any ideas?
we could commission FF to build us our own version of FF Mark
I think it's possible to change font names on a Mac. You could change the font's name to something like FF-UCS and have the ID doc reference that.
oof that's scary
Why?
We're just changing the filename of a font that we legally purchased just for internal purposes.

we should just make sure that everyone here is using the same version of FF Mark. Which we probably already are... I know I got mine from Matt or Ewald. We're not really sharing these files externally so it shouldnt be much of a problem
<@U02618EV1> that's not a bad idea for Gotham
Yes, don't think Mark would be nearly as problematic as Gotham.
<@U026NB2U2|marcelino> has joined the channel
(Not sure if I'm supposed to be here - feel free to boot me out)
Here's my one thought (then kick me out) would we ever use GitHub or some form of version control on the pitch decks?
The NAS is great for storing stuff, but not really for version control. I've probably asked everyone for what the "latest deck" is and I usually have to cobble things together.
that would be dope. I think Adobe CC has something like that for publication folks already built in.

i can look into it. This happens all the time at publishers too. How InDesign "packages" their files/fonts/images has always sucked. Which is why I think there is something, either a feature or alternate product, that uses a GitHub type model.
<https://creative.adobe.com/products/incopy>

I am all for version control....but there's never going to be a single "latest deck"— there will be decks for proposals, there will be decks for design, there will be wireframe decks... each has its own particular needs. I supposed we could make one big master document that has every page type... but like Matt said, everything is customizable to a point.
hm, interesting
if everyone can handle rocking the gotham decks (pitch & client facing) for a little longer, I can fast-track an update to both. I think a refresh with better fonts will fix 90% of these pain points.
I remember looking into github for design files last year and the problem with it was the file size. I saved every version of file so file sizes got crazy with PSD files.
CC has a ton of storage built in
Was more of a sharing and open files concern. We're talking about 5gb for a simple PSD
But, thoughts and pain-points are appreciated everyone. I'll try to figure something out going forward
That said, I think CC has their own system so they probably deal with this differently.
